derivation.yuyuan_name: Middle English (in sense 2): from Anglo-Norman French suffraunce, from late Latin sufferentia, from sufferre (see suffer)

entry.def: If you are allowed to do something on sufferance, you can do it, although you know that the person who gave you permission would prefer that you did not do it.

example.ex: His party held office on sufferance...
The civilian authorities are only there on sufferance of the military.
example.tran: 政府当局人员是在军方勉强同意后才到达那里的。

means.word_mean: 1. patient endurance especially of pain or distress
2. a disposition to tolerate or accept people or situations;

sentences.sentence: "all people should practice toleration and live together in peace"

auth_sentence.content: Mithridates was once more a petty Asiatic prince existing upon sufferance.
